step_1.description: The paper explicitly states that DJ-1 mutations are recessive and likely to cause loss of function, defining the disease mechanism.

step_2.description: Assays (protein stability, proteasome inhibition, subcellular localization) directly relate to the disease mechanism of loss of function.

step_3a.description: The paper references wildtype (wt) as a control and compares variant effects (e.g., 'protein levels were rescued in part... by proteasome inhibition'), implying controls.

step_3b.description: The methods (protein stability, localization) are standard in the field, as referenced by prior studies ([3,4,14]).

step_3c.description: The paper does not explicitly mention variant controls (e.g., known pathogenic/benign variants) for L166P or M26I.

step_4a.description: No statistical analyses (e.g., p-values, OddsPath) are reported for L166P or M26I.

step_4b.description: Total variant controls used in the study: L166P, M26I, and R98Q (3 variants).
